In Java, one of the most important things you'll work with is Strings. But what exactly is a String?
Think of a String as a line of text—like a word, a sentence, or even a whole paragraph. In Java, strings are objects that hold sequences of characters, like "Hello" or "I love coding!"
String is a Class, Not a Data Type
No! Yes, you read that correctly. Even though you can use a String like a basic data type in Java, it is actually an object of the String class (in java.lang package), which provides various built-in methods for manipulating and handling text efficiently.
Understand String With An Example

Let’s break this down line-by-line, and see what’s happening!
1. String s = "Hello";
Here, we’re creating a String variable named s and assigning it the value "Hello". Think of s as a box that holds the word "Hello".
2. int len = s.length();
The .length() method tells us how many characters are in the string. Length of 'Hello' is 5 ("Hello" has 5 letters: H, e, l, l, o)
3. String s1 = s.concat("World");
The .concat() method adds another string to the end of the first one. It doesn’t change the original string s, it creates a new one. So s1 is a new string that combines "Hello" + "World".
4. System.out.println(s.charAt(1));
The .charAt(index) method gives us the character at a specific position. (Index starts from 0). "Hello" → H(0), e(1), l(2), l(3), o(4) → So index 1 = 'e'
5. System.out.println(s.endsWith("lo"));
The .endsWith("lo") checks if the string ends with "lo". "Hello" does end with "lo", so the answer is true.
6. System.out.println(s.indexOf("l"));
This returns the index of the first occurrence of a character. The first 'l' in "Hello" is at index 2.
7. System.out.println(s.lastIndexOf("l"));
This returns the index of the last occurrence of a character. The last 'l' in "Hello" is at index 3.
8. System.out.println(s.replace("l", "v"));
This replaces all occurrences of a letter with another. And returns new string.
9. System.out.println(s.startsWith("H"));
Checks if the string starts with the letter "H". "Hello" starts with H → so it returns true.
10. System.out.println(s.toLowerCase());
Changes all letters to lowercase. And returns new string.
11. System.out.println(s.toUpperCase());
Changes all letters to uppercase. And returns new string.
There are many more methods in the String class. You can find them here.
Coding Tips
Strings are powerful—you’ll use them almost everywhere in programming.These methods help you analyze, modify, or format your text easily.
Strings in Java are immutable—which means once created, they can't be changed. Any method that changes a string actually returns a new string.
